sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Natpara(R) is available only through the Natpara REMS program (www.natpararems.com or 1-855-NATPARA) because of the risk of osteosarcoma.
  • Confirm there are sufficient 25-hydroxyvitamin D stores and that serum calcium (albumin-adjusted) greater than 7.5 mg/dL before initiating therapy.
  • Hypocalcemia - Hypoparathyroidism: Initial: 50 mcg subQ once daily; increase as needed in 25-mcg increments every 4 weeks; MAX dose, 100 mcg/day; dose may be decreased to 25 mcg/day if needed; maintenance dose should be lowest dose required to prevent hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria (usually the dose that keeps serum calcium [albumin-adjusted] at lower end of normal [8 to 9 mg/dL] without requiring active vitamin D therapy); adjust vitamin D and calcium doses during therapy

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Hepatic impairment, mild to moderate (Child-Pugh A or B): No adjustment necessary
  • Geriatric: Use caution and start at low end of dosing range

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Subcutaneous (Powder for Solution)
Parathyroid hormone increased the incidence of osteosarcoma in rats with occurrence dependent on treatment duration and dose. Therefore, use parathyroid hormone only in patients that cannot be controlled with calcium and active forms of vitamin D alone and for whom the potential benefits outweigh the potential risks. Avoid use in patients with an increased baseline risk for osteosarcoma (eg, Paget disease of bone, unexplained elevations of alkaline phosphatase, pediatric and young adults with open epiphyses, hereditary disorders predisposing to osteosarcoma, and history of external beam or implant radiation therapy involving the skeleton). Parathyroid hormone is only available through a restricted program under a Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy (REMS) called the Natpara REMS program.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- Osteosarcoma may occur; avoid use in at risk patients; monitoring for clinical signs/symptoms recommended
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Severe hypercalcemia has been reported; monitoring recommended; interruption or dose reduction may be required
  • -- Severe hypocalcemia has been reported, typically during interruption or discontinuation of therapy; monitoring recommended
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Antibody formation may occur
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Concomitant use with alendronate not recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (12%), Vomiting (12%)
  • Immunologic:Antibody development (8.6% to 16.1%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (11%), Pain in limb (10%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (25%), Hypesthesia (14%; facial, 6%), Paresthesia (31%)
  • Renal:Hypercalciuria, Or urine calcium increased (11%)
Serious
Endocrine metabolic:Hypercalcemia, Or serum calcium increased (19%), Hypocalcemia, Or serum calcium decreased (27%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Parathyroid hormone raises serum calcium levels through increased absorption through the intestines, increased reabsorption at the renal tubules, and increased bone turnover.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • Reconstitute medication cartridge with provided mixing device.
  • Store reconstituted medication cartridge in the Q-Cliq pen in the refrigerator for up to 14 days; discard any leftover medication after 14 days.
  • Do not freeze or shake.
  • Administer subQ into the thigh; rotate thighs daily.
  • Give a missed dose as soon as possible; administer additional calcium if hypocalcemia occurs; severe hypocalcemia may develop with abrupt discontinuation of therapy and resumption of or dose increases of vitamin D and calcium supplementation are required.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Control of hypocalcemia in patients with hypoparathyroidism is indicative of efficacy
  • Serum calcium; 3 to 7 days after treatment initiation or after dose adjustments to parathyroid hormone, active forms of vitamin D, or calcium; periodically after maintenance dose is achieved; and with abrupt withdrawal or discontinuation
  • Twenty-four hour urinary calcium; periodically after maintenance dose is achieved
  • Signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia; during therapy
  • Signs and symptoms of hypocalcemia; with abrupt treatment interruption or discontinuation

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Natpara
Subcutaneous Powder for Solution: 25 MCG, 50 MCG, 75 MCG, 100 MCG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Tell patient to report symptoms of an osteosarcoma.
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of hypocalcemia, hypercalcemia, or hypercalciuria.
  • Side effects may include paresthesia, hypoesthesia, headache, nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, arthralgia, or limb pain.
  • Teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
  • Tell patient to report abrupt treatment interruption or discontinuation, as hypocalcemia can develop.
  • Direct patient that if a dose is missed, administer the next dose as soon as feasible.
